page.title: 06OVERY SEASHORE WILDLIFE
page.content: Most Overy wildlife lives on the marsh and seashore. In summer there is a wide variety of crabs, shell creatures and birds. The crabs which are edible are further out to sea and the gillies which are usually found in damp places are under stones when the tide is out. If you go on to the beach and look for holes in the sand and a worm cast these are the markings of a lugworm which are usually used for bait when going fishing. At the end of summer there are a lot of jellyfish as small as a 50p coin. Cuttle fish are rare to find near the shore but you can find their bones in the tide line amongst seaweeds which have been washed up by the tide. Flat Fish, Bass Mullet and Sea Trout come in through the Creek at Burnham Overy.
